qas.question: Which snakes are considered native to the British Isles but not Ireland?

answers.text: European adder, the grass snake and the smooth snake

qas.question: What is the name of the slug that is native to both Britain and Ireland?
Is the grass nake or the smooth snake native to Ireland?
What type of wild life are not native to Ireland but are in Britain?

answers.text: water voles, roe deer and common toads

plausible_answers.text: the common European adder, the grass snake and the smooth snake

qas.question: Which four snakes are native to Ireland?
In Great Britain and what other country are there a large number of reptile species?
Certain species of wood lice are native to Great Britain but not where?
In Great Britain and what other country are there a large number of amphibian species?
In Ireland and what other country are there a large number of reptile species?

context: Few species of reptiles or amphibians are found in <b8_0>Great Britain<b8_0/> or <b5_0><b7_0>Ireland<b7_0/><b5_0/>. Only three snakes are native to Great Britain: <b4_0>the common <a0_0>European adder, the grass snake and the smooth snake<b4_0/><a0_0/>; <a2_0>none are native to Ireland<a2_0/>. In general, Great Britain has slightly more variation and native wild life, with weasels, polecats, wildcats, most shrews, moles, <a3_0>water voles, roe deer and common toads<a3_0/> also being absent from Ireland. This pattern is also true for birds and insects. Notable exceptions include the <a1_0>Kerry slug<a1_0/> and certain species of wood lice native to <b6_0>Ireland<b6_0/> but not Great Britain.
